content: quote: Originally posted by azmax64: There is always room for concern But, the News does seem to be making it out to be the black plaque. The plague is always present out west here (you didn't know that?). Ground squirrels, such as prairie dogs, chipmunks, and such carry it all the time. About the only time people get it is if they mess around with the critters in some way, letting them get into their camp gear/supplies, etc...or as in one case, killing and eating them during "Survival Hikes" which are often conducted by "get down to earth" types in the South West Deserts. Fleas and lice are still the common vectors... The last case I heard of, a young person on a survival hike was killing and eating ground squirrels. After he got home he got very sick, boils in armpits etc... They thought it was Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, often gotten from ticks, but no... Had them stumped, but a doctor from India or Pakistan recognized the symptoms. I can't remember if the kid died or not, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics if recognized soon enough, because it's a bacteria. This is not to be confused with Haunta Virus or West Nile Virus which are also sweeping the West and killing people every year. These, like Flu, are caused by viruses are are very difficult to treat. Haunta Virus is native to the South West Desert, is carried by mice and is contracted by breathing dust from there droppings while cleaning out sheds etc. with a very high percent (70-80%) fatality in a very short period of time. West Nile is mosquito borne, like malaria, and causes flu-like symptoms which most people don't associate with a bite, and never report. In a few, it goes ballistic and usually kills them. Of course, those usually end up in hospitals, so the disease is identified, causing alarm. Survival rate is about the same as most bad types of Flu. Drain and spraying mosquito habitat goes a long way to preventing this one, along with the use of deet during twilight and dawn of warm days when the mosquito is about - - As for this most recent outbreak of Flu, I would still guess that the reason Mexicans are suffering such high mortality rate may be due to the Age-Old Native American lack of immunity to diseases originating in Euro-Asia. A high percentage of Mexicans still have pure or near pure Native American ancestry. Smallpox and other such diseases may have killed 3-4,000,000 American Indians as the Colonists and Pioneers move Westward, as compared to the much fewer numbers that were killed in conflicts and removals. That situation may be again happening - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by azmax64: There is always room for concern But, the News does seem to be making it out to be the black plaque. The plague is always present out west here (you didn't know that?). Ground squirrels, such as prairie dogs, chipmunks, and such carry it all the time. About the only time people get it is if they mess around with the critters in some way, letting them get into their camp gear/supplies, etc...or as in one case, killing and eating them during "Survival Hikes" which are often conducted by "get down to earth" types in the South West Deserts. Fleas and lice are still the common vectors... The last case I heard of, a young person on a survival hike was killing and eating ground squirrels. After he got home he got very sick, boils in armpits etc... They thought it was Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, often gotten from ticks, but no... Had them stumped, but a doctor from India or Pakistan recognized the symptoms. I can't remember if the kid died or not, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics if recognized soon enough, because it's a bacteria. This is not to be confused with Haunta Virus or West Nile Virus which are also sweeping the West and killing people every year. These, like Flu, are caused by viruses are are very difficult to treat. Haunta Virus is native to the South West Desert, is carried by mice and is contracted by breathing dust from there droppings while cleaning out sheds etc. with a very high percent (70-80%) fatality in a very short period of time. West Nile is mosquito borne, like malaria, and causes flu-like symptoms which most people don't associate with a bite, and never report. In a few, it goes ballistic and usually kills them. Of course, those usually end up in hospitals, so the disease is identified, causing alarm. Survival rate is about the same as most bad types of Flu. Drain and spraying mosquito habitat goes a long way to preventing this one, along with the use of deet during twilight and dawn of warm days when the mosquito is about - - As for this most recent outbreak of Flu, I would still guess that the reason Mexicans are suffering such high mortality rate may be due to the Age-Old Native American lack of immunity to diseases originating in Euro-Asia. A high percentage of Mexicans still have pure or near pure Native American ancestry. Smallpox and other such diseases may have killed 3-4,000,000 American Indians as the Colonists and Pioneers move Westward, as compared to the much fewer numbers that were killed in conflicts and removals. That situation may be again happening - - Wandering and Wondering

Fleas and lice are still the common vectors... The last case I heard of, a young person on a survival hike was killing and eating ground squirrels. After he got home he got very sick, boils in armpits etc... They thought it was Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, often gotten from ticks, but no... Had them stumped, but a doctor from India or Pakistan recognized the symptoms. I can't remember if the kid died or not, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics if recognized soon enough, because it's a bacteria. This is not to be confused with Haunta Virus or West Nile Virus which are also sweeping the West and killing people every year. These, like Flu, are caused by viruses are are very difficult to treat. Haunta Virus is native to the South West Desert, is carried by mice and is contracted by breathing dust from there droppings while cleaning out sheds etc. with a very high percent (70-80%) fatality in a very short period of time. West Nile is mosquito borne, like malaria, and causes flu-like symptoms which most people don't associate with a bite, and never report. In a few, it goes ballistic and usually kills them. Of course, those usually end up in hospitals, so the disease is identified, causing alarm. Survival rate is about the same as most bad types of Flu. Drain and spraying mosquito habitat goes a long way to preventing this one, along with the use of deet during twilight and dawn of warm days when the mosquito is about - - As for this most recent outbreak of Flu, I would still guess that the reason Mexicans are suffering such high mortality rate may be due to the Age-Old Native American lack of immunity to diseases originating in Euro-Asia. A high percentage of Mexicans still have pure or near pure Native American ancestry. Smallpox and other such diseases may have killed 3-4,000,000 American Indians as the Colonists and Pioneers move Westward, as compared to the much fewer numbers that were killed in conflicts and removals. That situation may be again happening - - I'm guessing a person with ethnic diversity would have more ability to produce anti-bodies for a wider variety of diseases. content: quote: I'm guessing a person with ethnic diversity would have more ability to produce anti-bodies for a wider variety of diseases. Guess it depends on where the diversity came from and for what... Read the book that has a title like "Germs, Guns, and Steel". It make an argument that Europeans did some well on the world stage not so much that they were the brightest or more gifted, but that every culture West of the Urals had been so exposed to so many variety of foods, climates and diseases that they had a level of physical tolerance/immunity that gave them a slight edge wherever they went. They applied this adaptability to everything that came along, which resulted in steel and guns, though other cultures had all the makes much sooner - - I'm not certain I bit off on all of it - but the tolerance of deadly diseases seemed to make a whole lot of sense in many clime Europeans wandered or blundered into. It was usually the local population that died off from introduced European illness instead of vice versa - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: Just give it another week or two at the most and then let's see how seriously everyone takes this. If it will make you feel any better and more able to rationalize "why" the WHO, CDC, and world governments are doing what they are... try thinking of all this as a huge FTX. Since you and most others are grasping for the incorrect response straws it will be a better way of understanding. It has nothing to do with the loss of life... nada, zilch! But it has all to do with stopping the spread of a highly communicable illness. And if you do not practice at it... how do you expect to stop a real bad one? No one is saying that this is a bad one (outside of the country of origin that is). In fact many representatives have stated just how mild it seems to be. But Viruses are strange little buggers... they mutate constantly and the more that escape (through widespread geographical infections) the more different and more virulent mutations will occur.
